question:
Question 1 The vector function [latex]F\left ( r \right )=-x\hat{i}+y\hat{j}[/latex]
 is defined over a circular arc C shown in the figure. The line integral of [latex]\int _{C} F\left ( r \right ).dr[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \bar{F} &=-x i+y j \\ \int \vec{F} \cdot \overrightarrow{d r} &=\int_{c}-x d x+y d y \\ &=\int_{\theta=0}^{45^{\circ}}(-\cos \theta(-\sin \theta)+\sin \theta \cos \theta) d \theta \\ \int_{\theta=0}^{\pi / 4} \sin 2 \theta d \theta &\left.=-\frac{\cos 2 \theta}{2}\right]_{0}^{\pi / 4} \\ &=-\frac{1}{2}[0-1]=\frac{1}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 2 Consider the differential equation given below. [latex]\frac{dy}{dx}+\frac{x}{1-x^{2}}y=x\sqrt{y}[/latex] The integrating factor of the differential equation is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{d y}{d x}+\frac{x}{1-x^{2}} y&=x \sqrt{y}, \quad \text { IF }=?\\ \text{Divided by }\sqrt{y}\\ \frac{1}{\sqrt{y}} \frac{d y}{d x}+\frac{x}{1-x^{2}} \sqrt{y}&=x \\ 2 \frac{d u}{d x}+\frac{x}{1-x^{2}} u&=x\\ \text{Let }\qquad x \sqrt{y}&=u\\ \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{v}} \frac{d y}{d x}&=\frac{d u}{d x}\\ \Rightarrow \qquad \frac{d u}{d x}+\frac{x}{2\left(1-x^{2}\right)} u&=\frac{x}{2} \rightarrow \text{ lines diff. equ.} \\ \text { I. } F&=e^{\int \frac{x}{2\left(1-x^{2}\right)} d x}=e^{-\frac{1}{4} \log \left(1-x^{2}\right)}&=e^{\log \left(1-x^{2}\right) \frac{-1}{4}} \\ \text { I.F }&=\frac{1}{\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{4}}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 3 Two continuous random variables X and Y are related as [latex]Y=2X+3[/latex] Let [latex]\sigma ^{2}_{X}[/latex] and [latex]\sigma ^{2}_{Y}[/latex] denote the variances of X and Y, respectively. The variances are related as
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Y &=2 X+3 \\ \operatorname{Var}[Y] &=E\left[(Y-\bar{Y})^{2}\right] \\ E[Y] &=\bar{Y}=2 \bar{X}+3 \\ \operatorname{Var}[Y] &=E\left[(2 X+3-2 \bar{X}-3)^{2}\right] \\ &=E\left[4(X-\bar{X})^{2}\right] \\ &=4 \cdot E\left[(X-\bar{X})^{2}\right] \\ \sigma_{Y}^{2} &=4 \cdot \sigma_{X}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 4 Consider a real-valued base-band signal x(t), band limited to [latex]\text{10 kHz}[/latex]. The Nyquist rate for the signal [latex]y\left ( t \right )=x\left ( t \right )x\left ( 1+\dfrac{t}{2} \right )[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\mathrm{NR}=2 \times f_{\mathrm{max}}=2 \times 15=30 \mathrm{kHz}[/latex]

question: Question 5 Consider two 16-point sequences x[n] and h[n]. Let the linear convolution of  x[n] and h[n] be denoted by y[n], while z[n] denotes the 16-point inverse discrete Fourier transform (IDFT) of the product of the 16-point DFTs of x[n] and h[n]. The value(s) of k for which z[k]=y[k] is/are
solution:
If two' N' point signals x(n) and h(n) are convolving with each other linearly and circularly then [latex]
y(k)=z(k)[/latex] at [latex]k=N-1[/latex] where, y(n)= Linear convolution of x(n) and h(n) z(n)= Circular convolution of x(n) and h(n) Since, [latex]N=16[/latex] (Given) Therefore, [latex]\quad y(k)=z(k)[/latex] at [latex]k=N-1=15[/latex]

question: Question 6 A bar of silicon is doped with boron concentration of [latex]10^{16} \text{cm}^{-3}[/latex]  and assumed to be fully ionized. It is exposed to light such that electron-hole pairs are generated throughout the volume of the bar at the rate of [latex]10^{20} \text{cm}^{-3} s^{-1}[/latex]. If the recombination lifetime is [latex]100 \;\mu s[/latex], intrinsic carrier concentration of silicon is [latex]10^{10} \text{cm}^{-3}[/latex] and assuming [latex]100\%[/latex] ionization of boron, then the approximate product of steady-state electron and hole concentrations due to this light exposure is
solution: Boron [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Acceptor type doping [latex] \begin{aligned} N_{A} &=10^{16} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3} \\ g_{0 p} &=1020 \mathrm{~cm}^{-3} \mathrm{~s}^{-1} \\ \tau &=100 \mu \mathrm{s} \\ n_{i} &=10^{10} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Product of steady state electron-hole concentration =? At thermal equilibrium (before shining light) [latex] \begin{array}{ll} \text { Hole concentration, } & p_{o} \simeq N_{A}=10^{16} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3} \\ \text { Electron concentration, } & n_{0}=\frac{n_{i}^{2}}{p_{0}}=\frac{10^{20}}{10^{16}}=10^{4} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3} \end{array}[/latex] After, illumination of light, Hole concentration, [latex]p=p_{o}+\delta p[/latex] Electron concentration, [latex]\quad n=n_{o}+\delta n[/latex] Due to shining light, excess carrier concentration, [latex] \begin{aligned} \delta p &=\delta n=g_{o p} \cdot \tau=10^{20} \times 100 \times 10^{-6}=10^{16} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3} \\ \therefore \qquad p &=10^{16}+10^{16}=2 \times 10^{16} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}\\ n&=10^{4}+10^{16} \simeq 10^{16} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3} \end{aligned}[/latex] So, product of steady state electron-hole concentration [latex] \begin{aligned} &=n p=10^{16} \times 2 \times 10^{16} \\ &=2 \times 10^{32} \mathrm{~cm}^{-6} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 7 The energy band diagram of a p-type semiconductor bar of length L under equilibrium condition (i.e.. the Fermi energy level [latex]E_{F}[/latex]
 is constant) is shown in the figure. The valance band [latex]E_{V}[/latex]
 is sloped since doping is non-uniform along the bar. The difference between the energy levels of the valence band at the two edges of the bar is [latex]\Delta[/latex]. If the charge of an electron is q, then the magnitude of the electric field developed inside this semiconductor bar is
solution: The built-in electric field is due to non-uniform doping (the semiconductor is under equilibrium) [latex]\begin{aligned} E &=\frac{1}{q}\frac{ d E_{v}}{d x} \\ &=\frac{1}{q} \frac{\Delta}{L} \\ &=\frac{\Delta}{q L} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Ignoring the body effect, the ac small signal voltage gain [latex]\left ( \partial V_{out}/\partial V_{in} \right )[/latex] of the circuit is

\begin{aligned}
\frac{V_{\text {out }}}{V_{\text {in }}} &=\frac{-g_{m 2} V_{g s}\left(r_{\infty} \| R_{\text {eq }}\right)}{V_{g s}} \\
A_{V} &=-g_{m 2}\left( \frac{1}{g_{m 1}}|| r_{o1} || r_{o 2} \right)

question: Question 9 For the circuit with an ideal OPAMP shown in the figure. [latex]V_{\text{REF}}[/latex] is fixed. If [latex]V_{\text{OUT}}=1[/latex] volt for [latex]V_{\text{IN}}-0.1[/latex] volt and [latex]V_{\text{OUT}}=6[/latex] volt for [latex]V_{\text{IN}}=1[/latex] volt, where [latex]V_{\text{OUT}}[/latex] is measured across [latex]R_{L}[/latex] connected at the output of this OPAMP, the value of [latex]R_{F}/R_{\text{IN}}[/latex] is
solution: MARKS TO ALL AS PER IIT ANSWER KEY [latex]\begin{aligned} V &=V^{+} \\ \frac{V_{\text {out }} R_{\text {in }}+V_{\text {in }} R_{F}}{R_{\text {in }}+R_{F}} &=\frac{V_{\text {ref }} R_{2}}{R_{1}+R_{2}} \\ \frac{1 \times R_{\text {in }}+0.1 \times R_{F}}{R_{\text {in }}+R_{F}} &=\frac{V_{\text {ref }} R_{2}}{R_{1}+R_{2}} &\ldots(i)\\ \frac{6 R_{\text {in }}+1 \times R_{F}}{R_{\text {in }}+R_{F}} &=\frac{V_{\text {ref }} R_{2}}{R_{1}+R_{2}} &\ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Equate equation (i) and (ii), [latex] \begin{aligned} 1 \times R_{\text {in }}+0.1 \times R_{F} &=6 \times R_{\text {in }}+1 \times R_{F} \\ -5 R_{\text {in }} &=0.9 R_{F} \\ \therefore \quad \frac{R_{F}}{R_{\text {in }}} &=\frac{-5}{0.9}=-5.55 \end{aligned}[/latex] (According to the given data magnitude is taken)

question: Question 10 Consider the circuit with an ideal OPAMP shown in the figure. Assuming [latex]\left | V_{\text{IN}} \right |\ll \left | V_{\text{CC}} \right |[/latex] and [latex]\left | V_{\text{REF}} \right |\ll \left | V_{\text{CC}} \right |[/latex] , the condition at which [latex]V_{\text{OUT}}[/latex] equals to zero is
solution: For ideal op-amp, [latex]V^{\prime}=V^{+}=0[/latex] KCL at node [latex]\mathrm{V}^{-}:[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{V_{\text {IN}}-0}{R}+\frac{\left(-V_{\text {REF }}-0\right)}{R}+\frac{V_{\text {OUT }}-0}{R_{F}} &=0 \\ \frac{V_{\text {OUT }}}{R_{F}} &=\frac{1}{R}\left(V_{\text {REF }}-V_{\text {IN }}\right) \\ V_{\text {OUT }} &=\frac{R_{F}}{R}\left(V_{\text {REF }}-V_{\text {IN }}\right)\\ \text { We want, }\qquad V_{\text {OUT }}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow\qquad V_{\text {REF }}-V_{\text {IN }}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow\qquad V_{\text {IN }}&=V_{\text {REF }} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 15 Consider a rectangular coordinate system (x,y,z) with unit vectors [latex]a_{x}\:a_{y}[/latex] and [latex]a_{z}[/latex]. A plane wave traveling in the region [latex]z\geq 0[/latex] with electric field vector [latex]E=10\cos\left ( 2\times 10^{8}t\:+\:\beta z\right )a_{y}[/latex] is incident normally on the plane at [latex]z=0[/latex], where [latex]\beta[/latex] is the phase constant. The region [latex]z\geq 0[/latex] is in free space and the region [latex]z \lt 0[/latex] is filled with a lossless medium (permittivity [latex]\varepsilon \:=\:\varepsilon _{0}[/latex], permeability [latex]\mu \:=\:4\mu _{0}[/latex] , where [latex]\varepsilon _{0}\:=\:8.85\times 10^{-12}\:\text{F/m}[/latex] and [latex]\mu _{0}\:=\:4\pi \times 10^{-7}\:\text{H/m})[/latex]. The value of the reflection coefficient is
solution: Given [latex]\vec{E}=10 \cos \left(2 \pi \times 10^{8} t+\beta z\right) \hat{a}_{y}[/latex] for [latex]z \geq 0[/latex] having free space. For [latex]z \lt  0[/latex] medium has [latex] \epsilon_{r 2}=1 ; \mu_{r 2}=4[/latex] [latex] \Gamma=\frac{\eta_{2}-\eta_{1}}{\eta_{2}+\eta_{1}}=\frac{120 \pi(2)-120 \pi}{120 \pi(2)+120 \pi}=\frac{1}{3}[/latex]

question: Question 16 If the vectors [latex](1.0,\:-1.0,\:2.0), (7.0,\:3.0,\:x)[/latex] and [latex](2.0,\:3.0,\:1.0)[/latex] in [latex]\mathbb{R}^{3}[/latex] are linearly dependent, the value of x is __________
solution: [latex](1,-1,2)[/latex] [latex] (7,3, x) [/latex] are linearly dependent when x=? [latex] (2,3,1) [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow\left|\begin{array}{ccc} 1 & -1 & 2 \\ 7 & 3 & x \\ 2 & 3 & 1 \end{array}\right| &=0 \Rightarrow 1(3-3 x)+1(7-2 x)+2(15)=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad-5 x&=-40 \\ x&=8 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 17 Consider the vector field [latex]F\:=\:a_{x}\left ( 4y-c_{1}z \right )+a_y\left ( 4x + 2z\right )+a_{z}\left ( 2y +z\right )[/latex] in a rectangular coordinate system (x,y,z) with unit vectors [latex]a_{x},\:a_{y}[/latex] and [latex]a_{z}[/latex]. If the field F is irrotational (conservative), then the constant [latex]c_{1}[/latex]
 (in integer) is _________________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \nabla \times \vec{F}&=0\\ \left|\begin{array}{ccc} i & j & k \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ 4 y-c_{1} z & 4 x+2 z & 2 y+z \end{array}\right|&=0\\ =i(2-2)-j\left(0+c_{1}\right)+k(4-4)=0 \\ c_{1} &=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 20 An 8-bit unipolar (all analog output values are positive) digital-to-analog converter (DAC) has a full-scale voltage range from [latex]0\; V[/latex]
 to [latex]7.68\:V[/latex]. If the digital input code is [latex]10010110[/latex]
 (the leftmost bit is [latex]\text{MSB}[/latex]), then the analog output voltage of the DAC (rounded off to one decimal place) is ___________ V.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Given: } \qquad \qquad V_{p s}&=7.68 \mathrm{~V} \\ n &=8 \mathrm{bit} \\ \text { Resolution }(k) &=\frac{V_{F S}}{2^{n}-1}=\frac{7.68}{2^{8}-1}=0.03\\ \text { Now, } \quad V_{\mathrm{DAC}}&=k \times\{\text { Decimal equivalent }\}\\ &=0.03 \times\{150\} \\ &=4.5 \mathrm{~V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

solution: Average power [latex][X(t)]=R_{x}(0)=2[/latex]

question: Question 22 Consider a carrier signal which is amplitude modulated by a single-tone sinusoidal message signal with a modulation index of [latex]50\%[/latex]. If the carrier and one of the sidebands are suppressed in the modulated signal, the percentage of power saved (rounded off to one decimal place) is ______________
solution: If carrier and one of the sidebands are suppressed, then % of power saved [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{\text { Power saved }}{\text { Total power }}=\frac{P_{c}+\frac{P_{c} \mu^{2}}{4}}{P_{c}\left[1+\frac{\mu^{2}}{2}\right]}=\frac{4+\mu^{2}}{4+2 \mu^{2}} \\ &=\frac{4+(0.5)^{2}}{4+2 \times(0.5)^{2}}=0.944=94.4 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 23 A speech signal, band limited to [latex]4\:\text{kHz}[/latex], is sampled at 1.25 times the Nyquist rate. The speech samples, assumed to be statistically independent and uniformly distributed in the range [latex]-5\:V[/latex] to [latex]+5\:V[/latex], are subsequently quantized in an 8-bit uniform quantizer and then transmitted over a voice-grade [latex]\text{AWGN}[/latex] telephone channel. If the ratio of transmitted signal power to channel noise power is [latex]26\:\text{dB}[/latex], the minimum channel bandwidth required to ensure reliable transmission of the signal with arbitrarily small probability of transmission error (rounded off to two decimal places) is _____ [latex]\text{kHz}[/latex].
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f_{m}&=4 \mathrm{kHz} \\ f_{s}&=1.25 \mathrm{NR}=1.25 \times\left(2 f_{m}\right)=10 \mathrm{kHz} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] n=8[/latex] bits/sample and [latex]\frac{S}{N}=26 \mathrm{~dB}=10^{2.6}[/latex] For arbitrarily small probability of transmission error, [latex] \begin{aligned} C & \geq R_{b} \Rightarrow B \log _{2}\left(1+\frac{S}{N}\right) \geq n f_{S} \\ \text{Blog}_{2}\left(1+10^{2.6}\right) & \geq 8 \times 10 \mathrm{~K} \Rightarrow B \geq 9.25 \mathrm{kHz} \\ B_{\min } &=9.25 \mathrm{kHz} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 24 A [latex]4\:kHz[/latex] sinusoidal message signal having amplitude [latex]4\:V[/latex] is fed to a delta modulator (DM) operating at a sampling rate of [latex]32\:\text{kHz}[/latex]
. The minimum step size required to avoid slope overload noise in the DM (rounded off to two decimal places) is _____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f_{m}&=4 \mathrm{kHz} \\ A_{m}&=4 \mathrm{~V} \\ f_{s}&=32 \mathrm{kHz}\\ \text { To avoid } \text{SOE} \rightarrow &\frac{\Delta}{T_{s}} \geq 2 \pi f_{m} A_{m} \\ \Delta \times 32 k &\geq 2 \pi \times 4 k \times 4 \mathrm{~V} \\ \Delta &\geq \pi\\ (\Delta)_{\min }&=\pi volts\\ (\Delta)_{\min }&=3.14 volts \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 25 The refractive indices of the core and cladding of an optical fiber are 1.50 and 1.48, respectively. The critical propagation angle, which is defined as the maximum angle that the light beam makes with the axis of the optical fiber to achieve the total internal reflection, (rounded off to two decimal places) is _____ degree.
solution: Given that Refractive index of core [latex]\eta_{1}=1.50 [/latex] Refractive index of clad [latex]\eta_{2}=1.48 [/latex] Critical propagation angle [latex]\left(\theta_{P}\right)[/latex] [latex] \theta_{P}=\sin ^{-1}\left[ \frac{ \sqrt{\eta_{1}^{2}-\eta_{2}^{2}}}{\eta_{1}}    \right]=\sin ^{-1} \left[  \frac{  \sqrt{1.5^{2}-1.48^{2}} }{1.5} \right] =9.37[/latex]

question: Question 26 Consider the integral [latex]\oint _{c}\frac{sin\left ( x \right )}{x^{2}\left ( x^{2}+4 \right )}dx[/latex] where C is a counter-clockwise oriented circle defined as [latex]\left | x-i \right |=2[/latex]. The value of the integral is
solution: MARKS TO ALL AS PER IIT ANSWER KEY [latex]\oint_{c} \frac{\sin x}{x^{2}\left(x^{2}+4\right)} d x, c:|x-i|=2[/latex] Poles are given by [latex]x^{2}=0[/latex] and [latex]x^{2}+4=0[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow\qquad x=0[/latex] is a pole of order '2' [latex] x=2[/latex] i are simple nodes [latex] x=0[/latex] lies inside 'c' [latex] x=2[/latex] i lies inside 'c' [latex] x=-2[/latex] i lies outside 'c' [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Res}_{0} &=\frac{1}{(2-1)} \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{d}{d z}\left[(x-0)^{2} \frac{\sin x}{x^{2}\left(x^{2}+4\right)}\right] \\ &=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\left(x^{2}+4\right) \cos x-\sin x(2 x)}{\left(x^{2}+4\right)^{2}}=\frac{1}{4} \\ \text{Res}_{2 i} &=\lim _{x \rightarrow 2 i}(x-2 i) \frac{\sin x}{x^{2}(x-2 i)(x+2 i)}=\frac{\sin (2 i)}{(-4)(4 i)} \\ \text{By CRT}\quad \oint_{c} f d x &=2 \pi i\left[\text{Res}_{0}+\text{Res}_{2 i}\right]=2 \pi i\left[\frac{1}{4}+\frac{\sin (2 i)}{-16}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 27 Box contains the following three coins. i.   A fair coin with head on one face and tail on the other face. ii.  A coin with heads on both the faces. iii. A coin with tails on both the faces. A coin is picked randomly from the box and tossed. Out of the two remaining coins in the box, one coin is then picked randomly and tossed. If the first toss results in a head, the probability of getting a head in the second toss is
solution: Let [latex]\quad P\left(H_{2}\right)=[/latex] Probability of getting head in second toss [latex] P\left(H_{1}\right)=[/latex] Probability of getting head in first toss [latex] \begin{aligned} P\left(\frac{H_{2}}{H_{1}}\right) &=\frac{P\left(H_{2} \cap H_{1}\right)}{P\left(H_{1}\right)} \\ P\left(H_{1}\right) &=\frac{1}{3} \times \frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{3} \times 1+\frac{1}{3} \times 0=\frac{1}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] To get head in second toss when head came in first toss, following cases can be made 1. Fair coin : [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Both head coin }=\frac{1}{3} \times \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{2} \times 1=\frac{1}{12} \\ \text { Both tail coin }=\frac{1}{3} \times \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{2} \times 0=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] 2. Both head coin : [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Fair coin }&=\frac{1}{3} \times 1 \times \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{2}=\frac{1}{12}\\ \text{Both tail coin }&=0\\ \therefore \qquad P\left(H_{2} \cap H_{1}\right)&=\frac{1}{12}+\frac{1}{12}=\frac{1}{6} \\ \therefore \qquad P\left(H_{2} / H_{1}\right)&=\frac{1 / 6}{1 / 2}=\frac{1}{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 28 The switch in the circuit in the figure is in position P for a long time and then moved to position Q at time t=0. The value of [latex]\dfrac{dv\left ( t \right )}{dt}[/latex] at [latex]t=0^{+}[/latex] is
solution: Inductor and capacitors are connected to the inductance source for a long time, so these elements have reached steady state. [latex] \begin{aligned} i_{L}\left(0^{-}\right) &=\frac{20}{5 \mathrm{k} \Omega+5 \mathrm{k} \Omega+10 \mathrm{k} \Omega}=1 \mathrm{~mA} \\ \mathrm{~V}\left(0^{-}\right) &=10 \mathrm{~V} \\ t &=0^{+} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} i\left(0^{+}\right)+\frac{10}{5 k}+1 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~A} &=0 \\ i\left(\mathrm{O}^{+}\right) &=-3 \mathrm{~mA} \\ C \frac{d V\left(\mathrm{O}^{+}\right)}{d t} &=-3 \mathrm{~mA} \\ 1 \times 10^{-3} \frac{d V\left(\mathrm{O}^{+}\right)}{d t} &=-3 \mathrm{~mA} \\ \frac{d V\left(\mathrm{O}^{+}\right)}{d t} &=-3 \mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 29 Consider the two-port network shown in the figure. The admittance parameters, in siemens, are
solution: Write KCL at [latex]V_{1}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{1}&=\frac{V_{1}}{1}+\frac{V_{1}-V_{2}}{1}-3 V_{2} \\ I_{1}&=2 V_{1}-4 V_{2} \\ \text{Write KCL at }V_{2}\qquad I_{2}&=\frac{V_{2}}{1}+\frac{V_{2}-V_{1}}{1}\\ I_{2}&=-V_{1}+2 V_{2} \\ [y]&=\left[\begin{array}{cc} 2 & -4 \\ -1 & 2 \end{array}\right] \mho \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 30 For an n-channel silicon [latex]\text{MOSFET}[/latex] with [latex]10\:nm[/latex] gate oxide thickness, the substrate sensitivity [latex]\left ( \partial V_{T}/\partial \left | V_{BS} \right | \right )[/latex] is found to be [latex]50\:mV/V[/latex] at a substrate voltage [latex]\left | V_{BS} \right |=2V[/latex], where [latex]V_{T}[/latex] is the threshold voltage of the [latex]\text{MOSFET}[/latex]. Assume that, [latex]\left | V_{BS} \right | \gg 2\Phi _{B}[/latex], where [latex]q\Phi _{B}[/latex] is the separation between the Fermi energy level [latex]E_{F}[/latex] and the intrinsic level [latex]E_{i}[/latex] in the bulk. Parameters given are Electron charge [latex](q) = 1.6 \times 101^{-19}\:C[/latex] Vacuum permittivity [latex](\varepsilon _{0}) = 8.85 \times 10^{-12}\: F/m[/latex] Relative permittivity of silicon [latex](\varepsilon _{Si}) = 12[/latex] Relative permittivity of oxide [latex](\varepsilon _{ox}) = 4[/latex] The doping concentration of the substrate is
solution: Given, N -channel MOSFET [latex] \begin{aligned} t_{o x}&=10 \mathrm{~nm}=10 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{~cm} & \\ \frac{\partial V_{T}}{\partial\left|V_{B S}\right|}&=50 \mathrm{mV} / \mathrm{V}, & \left|V_{B S}\right|=2 \mathrm{~V} \\ \qquad q&=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C} & \left|V_{B S}\right|>>2 \phi_{B} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \epsilon_{o} &=8.85 \times 10^{-14} \mathrm{~F} / \mathrm{cm} \\ \epsilon_{r_{\mathrm{Si}}} &=12 \\ \epsilon_{r_{O x}} &=4 \end{aligned}[/latex] Threshold voltage, including body effect, [latex] V_{T}=\phi_{m s}+\frac{\sqrt{2 \epsilon_{s i} q N_{A}\left(2 \phi_{B}-V_{B S}\right)}}{C_{o x}}+2 \phi_{B}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{In question, we need, } \left|V_{B S}\right|&=\left|V_{S B}\right| \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad V_{T}&=\phi_{m s}+\frac{\sqrt{2 \epsilon_{s i} q N_{A}\left(2 \phi_{B}+V_{S B}\right)}}{C_{o x}}+2 \phi_{B}\\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad V_{T}&=\phi_{m s}+\frac{\sqrt{2 \epsilon_{s i} q N_{A}\left(2 \phi_{B}+\left|V_{S B}\right|\right)}}{C_{O x}}+2 \phi_{B}\\ \therefore \qquad\qquad \frac{\partial V_{T}}{\partial\left|V_{B S}\right|}&=0+\frac{\sqrt{2 \epsilon_{s i} q N_{A}}}{C_{O x}} \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2 \phi_{B}+\left|V_{S B}\right|}}+0\\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad 50 \times 10^{-3}&=\frac{\sqrt{2 \times 8.85 \times 10^{-14} \times 12 \times 1.6 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{~N}_{A}}}{\epsilon_{\alpha x} / t_{0 x}} \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{\left|V_{S B}\right|}}\\ \left(\frac{50 \times 10^{-3} \times 4 \times 8.85 \times 10^{-14}}{10 \times 10^{-7}}\right)^{2}&=\frac{2 \times 8.85 \times 10^{-14} \times 12 \times 1.6 \times 10^{-19}}{4 \times 2}\\ &\left[\because\left|V_{S B}\right| \gt \gt 2 \phi_{B}\right]\\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad N_{A}&=7.375 \times 10^{15} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 31 The propagation delays of the XOR gate, AND gate and multiplexer (MUX) in the circuit shown in the figure are 4 ns, 2 ns and 1 ns, respectively. If all the inputs P, Q, R, S and T are applied simultaneously and held constant, the maximum propagation delay of the circuit is

question: Question 33 The electrical system shown in the figure converts input source current [latex]i_{s}(t)[/latex] to output voltage [latex]v_{o}(t)[/latex] Current i [latex]i_{L}(t)[/latex] in the inductor and voltage [latex]v_{c}(t)[/latex] across the capacitor are taken as the state variables, both assumed to be initially equal to zero, i.e., [latex]i_{L}(0) =0[/latex] and [latex]v_{c}(0)=0[/latex]. The system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} i_{s} &=v_{i}+v_{c} \\ \therefore \qquad v_{i} &=-v_{c}+i_{s} \\ v_{L} &=L i_{L} \\ v_{L} &=\left(i_{s}-i_{L}\right) \\ \therefore \qquad L i_{L} &=i_{s}-i_{L} \\ \therefore \qquad i_{L} &=-i_{L}+i_{s} \\ v_{o} &=v_{c} \\ X &=\left[\begin{array}{cc} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{array}\right] X+\left[\begin{array}{ll} 1 \\ 2 \end{array}\right] U \\ Y &=[0 \quad 1] X+[0] \cup \\ A &=-I \\ Q_{C} &=\left[\begin{array}{ll} B & A B \end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{ll} 1 & -1 \\ 1 & -1 \end{array}\right] \Rightarrow\left|Q_{c}\right|=0 \\ Q_{o} &=\left[\begin{array}{ll} C^{T} & A^{\top} C^{\top} \end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc} 0 & 0 \\ 1 & -1 \end{array}\right] \Rightarrow\left|Q_{o}\right|=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.A: completely state controllable as well as completely observable
options.B: completely state controllable but not observable

Question 35 The impedance matching network shown n the figure is to match a lossless line having characteristic impedance [latex]Z_{0}= 50 \:\Omega[/latex]
 with a load impedance [latex]Z_{L}[/latex]. A quarter-wave line having a characteristic impedance  [latex]Z_1=75\:\Omega[/latex]
 is connected to [latex]Z_{L}[/latex]. Two stubs having characteristic impedance of [latex]75\:\Omega[/latex]
 each are connected to this quarter-wave line. One is a short-circuited ([latex]\text{S.C}[/latex]) stub of length [latex]0.25\lambda[/latex]
 connected across PQ and the other one is an open-circuited [latex](\text{O.C})[/latex]
 stub of length [latex]0.5\lambda[/latex] connected across RS. The impedance matching in achieved when the real part of [latex]Z_{L}[/latex]
 is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_{\text {in } \lambda / 4}&=\frac{Z_{O}^{2}}{Z_{L}}=\frac{(75)^{2}}{0}=\infty \quad\left[\text { for } \frac{\lambda}{4} T_{X} \text { line }\right]\\ \text{Given }Z_{L}\text{ of }\frac{\lambda}{4}\text{ line is 0}(\mathrm{SC})\\ Z_{\text {in }_{\lambda / 2}}&=Z_{L}=\infty\left[\text { for } \frac{\lambda}{2} T_{X} \text { line }\right]\\ \text{Given }Z_{L}\text{ of }\frac{\lambda}{2}\text{ line is }\infty(O . C) \end{aligned}[/latex] The input impedance of [latex]\frac{\lambda}{4}[/latex] transmission line, as well as [latex]\frac{\lambda}{2}[/latex] transmission line is 00 , and they are in parallel with main transmission line, so they are not effective for main. Transmission line. Final configuration of given line is For impedance matching, [latex]Z_{L}=\frac{Z_{1}^{2}}{Z_{0}}=\frac{(75)^{2}}{50}=112.5[/latex]

question:
Question 36 A real [latex]2\times2[/latex]
 non-singular matrix A with repeated eigenvalue is given as [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} x & -3.0\\ 3.0 & 4.0 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] where x is a real positive number. The value of x (rounded off to one decimal place) is ________________
solution: [latex]A=\left[\begin{array}{cc} x & -3 \\ 3 & 4 \end{array} \right][/latex] Characteristic equation [latex] \begin{aligned} |A-\lambda I| &=\left|\begin{array}{cc} x-\lambda & -3 \\ 3 & 4-\lambda \end{array}\right|=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \lambda^{2}-(4+x) \lambda+(4 x+9)&=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] Roots are repeating [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \qquad b^{2}-4 a c&=0\\ \Rightarrow \qquad \left(4+x^{2}\right)-4(4 x+9) &=0 \\ 16+x^{2}+8 x-16 x-20 &=0 \\ x &=10 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad x^{2}-8 x+20 &=0\\ x&=\frac{8 \pm \sqrt{64+80}}{2} \\ &=\frac{8 \pm 12}{2}=-2,10 \end{aligned}[/latex] Since, x is positive [latex] \therefore x=10[/latex]

 in a cylindrical coordinate system [latex]\left ( \rho ,\varphi ,z \right )[/latex]
 with unit vectors [latex]a_{\rho },a_{\varphi }[/latex]

Question 38 In the circuit shown in the figure, the switch is closed at time [latex]t=0[/latex]
, while the capacitor is initially charged to [latex]-5\:V (i.e., v_{c}(0)=-5V)[/latex]
. The time after which the voltage across the capacitor becomes zero (rounded off to three decimal places) is ________________ [latex]\text{ms}[/latex].
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{c}\left(0^{-}\right)&=-5 \mathrm{~V} \\ V_{c}\left(0^{+}\right)&=-5 \mathrm{~V} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] t \rightarrow \infty,[/latex] capacitor acts as a O.C. Write KCL at node [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{V_{c}(\infty)-5}{250}+\frac{V_{R}}{500}+\frac{V_{c}(\infty)}{250} &=0 \\ V_{c}(\infty) &=\frac{5}{3} \text { Volts } \\ \text { Time constant }(\tau) &=R_{e q} C \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} I &=\frac{V}{250}+\frac{V_{R}}{500}+\frac{V}{250} \\ V_{R} &=-V \\ I &=\frac{V}{250}-\frac{V}{500}+\frac{V}{250} \\ \frac{V}{I} &=\frac{500}{3} \Omega ; R_{\mathrm{eq}}=\frac{500}{3} \Omega \\ \tau &=\frac{500}{3} \times 0.6 \mu=0.1 \times 10^{-3} \\ v_{c}(t) &=v_{c}(\infty)+\left(v_{c}(0)-v_{c}(\infty)\right) e^{-\sqrt{2}} \\ v_{c}(t) &=\frac{5}{3}+\left(-5-\frac{5}{3}\right) e^{-t / 0.1 \times 10^{-3}} \\ 0 &=\frac{5}{3}-\frac{20}{3} e^{-10000 t} \\ t &=0.1386 \mathrm{msec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 39 The exponential Fourier series representation of a continuous-time periodic signal x(t) is defined as [latex]x\left ( t \right )=\sum_{k=-\infty }^{\infty }a_{k}e^{jk\omega _{0}t}[/latex] where [latex]\omega _0[/latex] is the fundamental angular frequency of x(t) and the coefficients of the series are [latex]a_{k}[/latex]. The following information is given about [latex]x(t)[/latex]
 and [latex]a_{k}[/latex]. I.    x(t) is real and even, having a fundamental period of 6 II.  The average value of x(t) is 2 III. [latex]a_{k}=\left\{\begin{matrix} k, & 1\leq k\leq 3\\ 0,& k> 3 \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] The average power of the signal x(t) (rounded off to one decimal place) is ____________
solution: [latex]1. x(t)[/latex] is real and even so [latex]a_{k}[/latex] is also real and even [latex]a_{k}=a_{-k}[/latex] 2. Average of x(t) is 2 i.e., [latex]a_{0}=2.[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{llll} 3. \;x(t) \rightarrow a_{k}=k &1 \leq k \leq 3 \quad& a_{1}=1 \quad& a_{-1}=1 \\  \quad \quad \quad \quad \;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;0 & k>3 & a_{2}=2 & a_{-2}=2 \\ && a_{3}=3 & a_{-3}=3 \end{array}[/latex] [latex] 4. \quad T_{0}=6[/latex] Parsval's Power Theorem [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T}\left|x(t)^{2}\right| d t &=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{+\infty}\left|a_{k}\right|^{2} \\ P(t) &=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{+\infty}\left|a_{k}\right|^{2}=\left|a_{-3}\right|^{2}+\left|a_{-2}\right|^{2}+\left|a_{-1}\right|^{2}+\left|a_{0}\right|^{2}+\left|a_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|a_{2}\right|^{2}+\left|a_{3}\right|^{2} \\ &=2\left|a_{1}\right|^{2}+2\left|a_{2}\right|^{2}+2\left|a_{3}\right|^{2}+\left|a_{0}\right|^{2} \\ &=2 \times 1^{2}+2 \times(2)^{2}+2(3)^{2}+(2)^{2} \\ &=2+8+18+4 \\ P_{x(t)} &=32 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 40 For a unit step input u[n], a discrete-time [latex]\text{LTI}[/latex]
 system produces an output signal [latex]\left ( 2\delta \left [ n+1 \right ] +\delta \left [ n \right ]+\delta \left [ n-1 \right ]\right )[/latex]. Let [latex]y[n][/latex]
 be the output of the system for an input [latex]\left ( \left ( \dfrac{1}{2} \right )^n u\left [ n \right ]\right )[/latex]. The value of [latex]y[0][/latex]
 is ______
solution:
The impulse response [latex]h(n)=s(n)-s(n-1) [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} h(n)=2 \delta(n+1)+\delta(n)&+ \delta(n-1)-2 \delta(n)-\delta(n-1)-\delta(n-1-1) \\ &=2 \delta(n+1)+\delta(n)+\delta(n-1)-2 \delta(n)-\delta(n-1)-\delta(n-2) \\ h(n) &=2 \delta(n+1)-\delta(n)-\delta(n-2) \\ \text{For input }\qquad x_{1}(n)&=(1 / 2)^{n} u(n) \text{ then output }
y_{1}(n)=x_{1}(n) * h(n)\\ y_{1}(n)&=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n} u(n) *[2 \delta(n+1)-\delta(n)-\delta(n-2)]\\ y_{1}(n)&=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n} u(n) * 2 \delta(n+1)-\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n} u(n) * \delta(n)-\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n} u(n) * \delta(n-2) \\ y_{1}(n)&=2\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n+1} u(n+1)-\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n} u(n)-\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n-2} u(n-2) \\ \left.y_{1}(n)\right|_{n=0} &=2\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{1} u(1)-\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{0} u(0)-\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{-2} u(-2) \\ &=1-1 \\ y_{1}(0) &=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 41 Consider the signals [latex]x\left [ n \right ]=2^{n-1}u\left [ -n+2 \right ][/latex]
 and [latex]y\left [ n \right ]=2^{-n+2}u\left [ n+1 \right ][/latex], where [latex]u[n][/latex]
 is the unit step sequence. Let [latex]X(e^{jw})[/latex]
 and [latex]Y(e^{jw})[/latex]
 be the discrete-time Fourier transform of [latex]x[n][/latex]
 and [latex]y[n][/latex], respectively. The value of the integral [latex]\frac{1}{2\pi } \int_{0}^{2\pi }X\left ( e^{j\omega } \right )Y\left ( e^{-j\omega } \right )d\omega[/latex] (rounded off to one decimal place) is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x[n] &=2^{n-1} u[-n+2] \\ y[n] &=2^{-n+2} u[n+1] \\ y[-n] &=2^{n+2} u[-n+1] \\ V &=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{2 \pi} X\left(e^{j \omega}\right) Y\left(e^{-j \omega}\right) d \omega &\ldots(i)\\ z[n] &=x[n] * y[-n] \\ z[n] & \rightarrow Z\left(e^{j \omega}\right) \\ z[n] &=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} Z\left(e^{j \omega}\right) e^{j \omega n} d \omega \\ \text { Put } n=0, \qquad z[0] &=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{2 \pi} Z\left(e^{j \omega}\right) d \omega &\ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Compare equations (i) and (ii) [latex] \begin{aligned} z[0] &=V \\ Z\left(e^{j \omega}\right) &=X\left(e^{j \omega}\right) Y\left(e^{-j \omega}\right) \\ \text{Apply IDTFT},\qquad Z[n] &=x[n] * y[-n]=x[n] * p[n]\\ \because \qquad p[n]&=y[-n]=2^{n+2} u[-n+1]\\ z[n] &=\sum_{k=-\infty}^{+\infty} 2^{k-1} u[-k+2] 2^{n-k+2} u[-n+k+1] \\ &=\sum_{k=-\infty}^{2} 2^{k-1} 1 \cdot 2^{n-k+2} u[k+1-n] \\ &=\sum_{k=-\infty}^{2} 2^{k-1+n-k+2} u[k+1-n] \\ z[n] &=\sum_{k=-\infty}^{2} 2^{n+1} u[k-n+1] \\ \text { Put } n=0,\qquad \qquad V &=z[0]=\sum_{k=-\infty}^{2} 2^{1} \cdot u[k+1]=2 \sum_{k=-1}^{2} 1=2[1+1+1+1] \\ V &=8 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 42 A silicon P-N junction is shown in the figure. The doping in the P region is [latex]5\times10^{16}\:cm^{-3}[/latex]
 and doping in the N region is [latex]10\times10^{16}\:cm^{-3}[/latex]. The parameters given are Built-in voltage [latex]\left ( \Phi _{\text{bi}} \right ) = 0.8\:V[/latex] Electron charge [latex](q) = 1.6\times10^{-19} C\:[/latex] Vacuum permittivity [latex]\left ( \varepsilon _{0} \right ) = 8.85\times10^{-12}\:F/m[/latex] Relative permittivity of silicon [latex]\left ( \varepsilon _{\text{Si}} \right ) = 12[/latex] he magnitude of reverse bias voltage that would completely deplete one of the two regions (P or N) prior to the other (rounded off to one decimal place) is _________V.
solution:
Given: [latex]\quad N_{A}=5 \times 10^{16} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3} \quad ; \quad N_{D}=10 \times 10^{16} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}[/latex] Built-in potential, [latex]\quad \phi_{\mathrm{bi}}=0.8 \mathrm{~V} [/latex] Electron charge, [latex]q=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}[/latex] Vacuum permittivity, [latex]\epsilon_{o}=8.85 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{~F} / \mathrm{m}=8.85 \times 10^{-14} \mathrm{~F} / \mathrm{cm}[/latex] Relative permittivity silicon, [latex]
 \epsilon_{\mathrm{si}}=12[/latex] [latex]
\Rightarrow [/latex] Doping on both sides is comparable, so smaller region would deplete first. So, depletion region width on N -side [latex]=x_{n}=0.2 \mu \mathrm{m}[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned} 
\Rightarrow \qquad x_{n}&=0.2 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~cm}\\
x_{n}&=\sqrt{\frac{2 \epsilon_{S i}}{q}\left(\frac{N_{A}}{N_{D}}\right)\left(\frac{1}{N_{A}+N_{D}}\right)\left(\phi_{b i}+V_{R}\right)}
\end{aligned}[/latex] where, [latex]V_{R} \rightarrow [/latex] Magnitude of reverse bias potential [latex]\begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad 0.2 \times 10^{-4}&=\sqrt{\frac{2 \times 12 \times 8.85 \times 10^{-14}}{1.6 \times 10^{-19}} \cdot \frac{5 \times 10^{16}}{10 \times 10^{16}} \cdot \frac{1}{\left(15 \times 10^{16}\right)}\left(\phi_{b i}+V_{R}\right)} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad \phi_{b j}+V_{R}&=9.039\\ \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad V_{R}&=9.039-0.8\\ \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad V_{R}&=8.239 \mathrm{~V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 43 An asymmetrical periodic pulse train [latex]v_{in}[/latex]
 of [latex]10\:V[/latex]
 amplitude with on-time [latex]T_{\text{ON}}=1\:ms[/latex]
 and off-time [latex]T_{\text{OFF}}=1\:\mu s[/latex]
 is applied to the circuit shown in the figure. The diode [latex]D_{1}[/latex] is ideal. The difference between the maximum voltage and minimum voltage of the output waveform [latex]v_{o}[/latex] (in integer) is ______________ V.
solution: [latex]V_{\text{in}} = 10 V:[/latex] Diode is ON [latex]\therefore [/latex]Capacitor charges upto [latex]10 \mathrm{~V},[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \qquad V_{C}&=10 \mathrm{~V} \\ V_{\text {in }}&=0 ; \text { Diode is OFF } \end{aligned}[/latex] Discharging time constant [latex]=R \times C[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &=10 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{sec} \\ \tau_{\text {discharging }} &>>\tau_{\mathrm{OFF}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Capacitor discharges negligibly [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore\qquad V_{C}&=10 \mathrm{~V}\\ \text{In steady state},\qquad V_{C} &=10 \mathrm{~V} \\ V_{\text {out }} &=V_{\text {in }}-V_{C}=V_{\text {in }}-10 \mathrm{~V}\\ \text{When }\qquad V_{\text {in }}&=10 \mathrm{~V}\\ \Rightarrow\qquad V_{\text {out }} &=10-10=0 \mathrm{~V} \\ V_{\text {in }} &=10 \mathrm{~V} \\ \mathrm{~V}_{\text {out }} &=0-10=-10 \mathrm{~V}\\ \Rightarrow\qquad V_{\text {out(max) }}-V_{\text {out(min) }}&=0-(-10)=10 \mathrm{~V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 44 For the transistor [latex]M_{1}[/latex]
 in the circuit shown in the figure, [latex]\mu_{n} C_{\text{ox}} = 100\:\mu A/V^{2}[/latex]
 and [latex](W/L)=10[/latex], where [latex]\mu_{n}[/latex]
 is the mobility of electron, [latex]C_{\text{ox}}[/latex] is the oxide capacitance per unit area , W is the width and L is the length. The channel length modulation coefficient is ignored. If the gate-to-source voltage [latex]V_{\text{GS}}\text{ is } 1\:V[/latex]
 to keep the transistor at the edge of saturation, then the threshold voltage of the transistor (rounded off to one decimal place) is _______ V.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{D S}&=\frac{\mu_{n} C_{O x}}{2} \times \frac{W}{L}\left(V_{G S}-V_{T}\right)^{2} \\ \text{Given}\qquad V_{G S}&=1 \mathrm{~V} \\ I_{D S}&=\frac{1}{2}\left(1-V_{T}\right)^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{D S}=3-20 \times I_{D S} \\ V_{D S}=3-\frac{20}{2}\left(1-V_{T}\right)^{2} \\ V_{D S}=3-10\left(1-V_{T}\right)^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] MOSFET operates in saturation if [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{D S} &\geq V_{G S}-V_{T}\\ \text{So, we take},\qquad \quad V_{D S}&=V_{G S}-V_{T} \\ V_{G S}-V_{T}&=3-10\left(1-V_{T}\right)^{2} \\ 1-V_{T}&=3-10\left(1-V_{T}\right)^{2}\\ \text{Let,}\qquad 1-V_{T} &=x \\ 3-10 x^{2} &=x \\ 10 x^{2}+x-3 x &=0 \\ \text{We get,}\qquad x &=-\frac{1 \pm \sqrt{1+120}}{20}\\ x &=-\frac{1 \pm 11}{20}\\ \therefore \qquad \quad x&=0.5 \text { and }-0.6\\ x&=0.5\\ \Rightarrow \qquad \quad 1-V_{T} & =0.5 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \quad V_{T} & =0.5 \mathrm{~V} \\ x & =-0.6 \\ \Rightarrow\qquad \quad 1-V_{T} & =-0.6 \\ \Rightarrow\qquad \quad V_{T} & =1.6 \mathrm{~V} \\ \text { But }\qquad \quad V_{G S} & \gt V_{T} \\ \text { or }\qquad \quad V_{T} & \lt V_{G S} \\ \text { i.e., }\qquad \quad V_{T} &  \lt 1 \\ \therefore\qquad \quad V_{T} & =0.5 \mathrm{~V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

 with [latex]D_{2}=1[/latex], the minimum number of triggering clock edges after which the flip-flop outputs [latex]Q_{2}Q_{1}Q_{0}[/latex]

question: Question 47 The circuit in the figure contains a current source driving a load having an inductor and a resistor in series, with a shunt capacitor across the load. The ammeter is assumed to have zero resistance. The switch is closed at time t = 0. Initially, when the switch is open, the capacitor is discharged and the ammeter reads zero ampere. After the switch is closed, the ammeter reading keeps fluctuating for some time till it settles to a final steady value. The maximum ammeter reading that one will observe after the switch is closed (rounded off to two decimal places) is _______________ A.
solution: Apply Laplace transform, [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{s} &=\frac{V(s)}{1 / C s}+\frac{V(s)}{R+L s} \\ \frac{1}{s} &=V(s)\left[C s+\frac{1}{R+L s}\right] \\ V(s) &=\frac{(1 / s)}{C s+\frac{1}{R+L s}} \\ V(s) &=\frac{(1 / s)(R+L S)}{L C s^{2}+R C s+1} \\ I(s) &=\frac{(1 / s)(R+L s)}{L C s^{2}+R C s+1} \cdot \frac{1}{(R+L s)} \\ I(s) &=\frac{1 / L C}{s\left(s^{2}+\frac{R}{L} s+\frac{1}{L C}\right)} \\ L &=10 \mathrm{mH} ; C=100 \mathrm{pF} ; R=5 \times 10^{3} \Omega\\ \xi &=\frac{R}{2} \sqrt{\frac{C}{L}}=\frac{5 \times 10^{3}}{2} \sqrt{\frac{100 \times 10^{-12}}{10 \times 10^{-3}}}=0.25 \\ \text{Max}. \text { over shoot } &=e^{-\pi \xi / \sqrt{1-\xi^{2}}}=0.44 \end{aligned}[/latex] Maximum value = Steady state + Max. overshoot [latex] =1+0.44[/latex] [latex] =1.44 \mathrm{~A}[/latex]

question:
Question 48 A unity feedback system that uses proportional-integral ([latex]\text{PI}[/latex]
) control is shown in the figure. The stability of the overall system is controlled by tuning the [latex]\text{PI}[/latex] control parameters [latex]K_{P}[/latex]
 and [latex]K_{I}[/latex]. The maximum value of [latex]K_{I}[/latex]
 that can be chosen so as to keep the overall system stable or, in the worst case, marginally stable (rounded off to three decimal places) is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} G H &=\left(\frac{s K_{p}+K_{I}}{s}\right)\left(\frac{2}{s^{3}+4 s^{2}+5 s+2}\right) \\ q(s) &=s^{4}+4 s^{3}+5 s^{2}+s\left(2+2 k_{p}\right)+2 k_{I} \\ \text{Necessary}:\qquad K_{p} & \gt -1 ; K_{I} \gt 0\\ &\begin{array}{l|ccc} s^{4} & 1 & 5 & 2 K_{I} \\ s^{3} & 4 & 2+2 K_{p} & \\ s^{2} & \frac{18-2 K_{p}}{4} & 2 K_{I} & \\ s^{1} & \left(9-K_{p}\right)\left(1+K_{p}\right)-8 K_{I} & & \\ s^{0} & 2 K_{I} & & \end{array}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Sufficient: [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{18-2 K_{p}}{4}& \gt 0\\ \Rightarrow \quad K_{p}& \lt 9\\ \therefore \quad-1& \lt K_{p} \lt 9\\ \left(18-2 K_{p}\right)\left(2+2 K_{p}\right)-32 K_{I}& \gt 0\\ 32 K_{I}& \lt 36+32 K_{p}-4 K_{p}^{2}\\ \therefore \qquad \qquad 0& \lt K_{I} \lt \frac{36+32 K_{p}-4 K_{p}^{2}}{32} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{If }K_{p}&=-1 \Rightarrow k_{I}=0\\ \text{If }K_{p}&=9 \Rightarrow k_{I}=0\\ \end{aligned}[/latex], [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \qquad \qquad \frac{d K_{I}}{d K_{p}}&=0\\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad 32-8 K_{p}&=0=0 \Rightarrow K_{p}=4 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] For [latex]K_{p}=4, K_{I}[/latex] is maximum, which is [latex] K_{I}=\frac{36+32 \times 4-64}{32}=3.125[/latex] For [latex]K_{p}=4, K_{I} \lt 3.125[/latex] for stability [latex] \therefore K_{I \max }=3.125[/latex]

question:
Question 49 A sinusoidal message signal having root mean square value of [latex]4\:V[/latex]
 and frequency of [latex]\text{1 kHz}[/latex]
 is fed to a phase modulator with phase deviation constant 2 rad/ volt. If the carrier signal is [latex]c\left ( t \right )=2\cos\left ( 2\pi 10^{6} t\right )[/latex], the maximum instantaneous frequency of the phase modulated signal (rounded off to one decimal place) is ______ [latex]\text{Hz}[/latex]
.
solution: Given sinusoidal message signal [latex]\rightarrow V_{\mathrm{rms}}=4 \mathrm{~V}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} f_{m} &=1 \mathrm{kHz} \\ V_{\text {peak }} &=\sqrt{2} \times V_{\mathrm{rms}}=\sqrt{2} \times 4 \mathrm{~V} \\ m(t) &=4 \sqrt{2} \sin 2 \pi \times 10^{3} t\\ K_{p}&=2 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{volt}\\ c(t) &=2 \cos 2 \pi \times 10^{6} \mathrm{t} \\ \left(f_{i}\right)_{\max } &=f_{c}+\frac{K_{p}}{2 \pi}\left[\frac{d}{d t} m(t)\right]_{\max } \\ \frac{d}{d t} m(t) &=4 \sqrt{2} \times\left(2 \pi \times 10^{3}\right) \cos 2 \pi \times 10^{3} t \\ \left[\frac{d}{d t} m(t)\right]_{\max } &=4 \sqrt{2} \times 2 \pi \times 10^{3} \\ \left(f_{i}\right)_{\max } &=10^{6}+\frac{2}{2 \pi}\left(4 \sqrt{2} \times 2 \pi \times 10^{3}\right)=1011313.7 \mathrm{~Hz} \end{aligned}[/latex]

 signal to the mixer, the image frequency (in integer) is ____________________ [latex]\text{kHz}[/latex]
.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f_{s} &=600 \mathrm{kHz} \\ f_{l} &=1000 \mathrm{kHz} \\ f_{s i} &=? \\ \text { Default } f_{l}>f_{s} & \\ \mathrm{IF} &=f_{l}-f_{s}=400 \mathrm{kHz} \\ f_{\mathrm{si}} &=f_{s}+2 \mathrm{IF}=600 \mathrm{~K}+800 \mathrm{~K}=1400 \mathrm{kHz} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 51 In a high school having equal number of boy students and girl students, [latex]75\%[/latex]
 of the students study Science and the remaining [latex]25\%[/latex]
 students study Commerce. Commerce students are two times more likely to be a boy than are Science students. The amount of information gained in knowing that a randomly selected girl student studies Commerce (rounded off to three decimal places) is ______ bits.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given,}\qquad P(G)&=\frac{1}{2} \text { and } P(B)=\frac{1}{2} \\ P(C)&=\frac{1}{4} \text { and } P(S)=\frac{3}{4} \end{aligned}[/latex] Let probability of selected science student is a boy is [latex]P(B/S) = x[/latex] Given that Commerce students are two time more likely to be a boy than are Science students. Then, probability of selected Commerce student is a boy [latex] P\left(\frac{B}{C}\right)=2 x[/latex] We have to find probability of randomly selected girl studies Commerce i.e. [latex] \begin{aligned} P\left(\frac{C}{G}\right)&=\frac{P(C \cap G)}{P(G)}=\frac{P(C) P(G / C)}{P(G)} \\ P\left(\frac{C}{G}\right)&=\frac{\frac{1}{4} \times P\left(\frac{G}{C}\right)}{\frac{1}{2}} &\ldots(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] To find [latex]P(G / C)[/latex], first we have to find [latex]P(B/C).[/latex] The probability of selected student is a boy [latex]\begin{aligned} P(B) &=P(S) P(B / S)+P(C) \times P(B / C) \\ \frac{1}{2} &=\frac{3}{4} \times x+\frac{1}{4} \times 2 x \\ \Rightarrow\qquad\qquad x &=\frac{2}{5}\\ \text{Then},\qquad \qquad P(B / C)&=2 x=\frac{4}{5}\\ \text{We know that},\qquad \\ P\left(\frac{B}{C}\right)+P\left(\frac{G}{C}\right)&=1    \\ P\left(\frac{G}{C}\right) =1- \frac{4}{5}&=\frac{1}{5} \\ \text{From  equation (i),} \\ P\left(\frac{G}{C}\right) = \frac{1}{4} \times \frac{1}{\frac{5}{1/2}} &= \frac{1}{10} \end{aligned}[/latex] The amount of information gained in knowing that a randomly selected girl student studies Commerce [latex]I\left ( \frac{C}{G} \right )=\log _2 \frac{1}{P\left ( \frac{C}{G} \right )}= \log _2 10=3.32[/latex]

question:
Question 52 A message signal having peak-to-peak value of [latex]2\:V[/latex], root mean square value of [latex]0.1\:V[/latex]
 and bandwidth of [latex]\text{5 kHz}[/latex]
 is sampled and fed to a pulse code modulation [latex](\text{PCM})[/latex]
 system that uses a uniform quantizer. The [latex]\text{PCM}[/latex]
 output is transmitted over a channel that can support a maximum transmission rate of [latex]\text{50 kbps}[/latex]. Assuming that the quantization error is uniformly distributed, the maximum signal to quantization noise ratio that can be obtained by the [latex]\text{PCM}[/latex] system (rounded off to two decimal places) is  ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} v_{p-p} &=2 \mathrm{~V} \\ \text { Root MSQ }[m(t)] &=0.1 \mathrm{~V} ; \quad f_{m}=5 \mathrm{kHz} \\ \text { Channel capacity, } \quad C &=50 \mathrm{kbps} \\ \text{Max} \frac{S}{N_{Q}}=?\\ & \text{Signal power},\\ S&=\text{MSQ}[m(t)]=(0.1)^{2}=0.01\\ C &\geq R_{b} \Rightarrow 50 \mathrm{kbps} \geq n f_{s}\\ \because \qquad f_{s}&=N R=2 f_{m}=10 \mathrm{kHz}\\ n &\leq 5 \Rightarrow n_{\max }=5\\ N_{Q} &=\frac{\Delta^{2}}{12} \\ \therefore\qquad \Delta &=\frac{V_{p-p}}{2^{n}} \\ \Delta_{\min } &=\frac{V_{p-p}}{2^{7} \max }=\frac{2 V}{2^{5}}=\frac{1}{16} \\ \left(N_{Q}\right)_{\min } &=\frac{\Delta_{\min }^{2}}{12}=3.25 \times 10^{-4} \\ \left(\frac{S}{N Q}\right)_{\max } &=\frac{S}{\left(N_{Q}\right)_{\min }}=\frac{0.01}{3.25 \times 10^{-4}}=30.72 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 53 Consider a polar non-return to zero [latex](\text{NRZ})[/latex]
 waveform, using [latex]+2\:V[/latex]
 and [latex]-2\:V[/latex]
 for representing binary '1' and '0' respectively, is transmitted in the presence of additive zero-mean white Gaussian noise with variance [latex]0.4\:V^{2}[/latex]. If the a priori probability of transmission of a binary '1' is 0.4, the optimum threshold voltage for a maximum a posteriori [latex](\text{MAP})[/latex]
 receiver (rounded off to two decimal places) is ______ V.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} H_{1}: X &=+2 \mathrm{~V} \\ H_{0}: X &=-2 \mathrm{~V} \\ \text{Var}[N] &=\sigma_{n}^{2}=0.4 \mathrm{~V}^{2} \\ \mathrm{E}[\mathrm{N}] &=0 \\ P(1) &=0.4 \\ \Rightarrow\qquad P(0) &=0.6 \end{aligned}[/latex] Opt [latex]V_{\text {Th }}[/latex] by using MAP theorem [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{V_{T h}\left[a_{1}-a_{2}\right]}{\sigma^{2}}-\frac{a_{1}^{2}-a_{2}^{2}}{2 \sigma^{2}} &=\ln \frac{P(0)}{P(1)} \\ H_{1}: a_{1} &=E[2+N]=E[2]+E[N]=2 \\ H_{0}: a_{2} &=-2 V=E[-2+N]=E[-2]+E[N]=-2 \\ \sigma^{2} &=\text{Var}[Y]=\text{Var}[X+N] \\ &=\text{Var}[X]+\text{Var}[N]=0+0.4=0.4 \\ \frac{V_{T h}[2+2]}{0.4}-\frac{4-4}{2 \times 0.4} &=\ln \frac{0.6}{0.4} \\ V_{T h} &=\frac{0.4}{4} \ln \frac{0.6}{0.4}=0.0405 \\ \text { Opt } V_{\text {Th }} &=0.0405 \text { Volts } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 54 A standard air-filled rectangular waveguide with dimensions [latex]\text{a=8 cm, b=4 cm}[/latex], operates at [latex]\text{3.4 GHz}[/latex]. For the dominant mode of wave propagation, the phase velocity of the signal in [latex]v_{p}[/latex]. The value (rounded off to two decimal places) of [latex]v_{p}/c[/latex], where c denotes the velocity of light, is _____
solution: [latex]f_{c 10}=\frac{c}{2 a}=\frac{3 \times 10^{8}}{2\left(8 \times 10^{-2}\right)}=1.875 \mathrm{GHz}[/latex] Guide phase velocity,[latex] V_{p}=\frac{C}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{f_{C 10}}{f}\right)^{2}}} [/latex] [latex] \frac{V_{p}}{C}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{f_{C 10}}{f}\right)^{2}}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{1.875}{3.4}\right)^{2}}}=1.198[/latex]

question:
Question 55 An antenna with a directive gain of [latex]6\text{ dB}[/latex]
 is radiating a total power of [latex]\text{16 kW}[/latex]. The amplitude of the electric field in free space at a distance of [latex]\text{8 km}[/latex]
 from the antenna in the direction of [latex]\text{6 dB}[/latex]
 gain (rounded off to three decimal places) is  ______  [latex]\text{V/m}[/latex]
.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} G_{d}(\mathrm{~dB}) &=10 \log _{10}\left(G_{d}\right) \\ \Rightarrow\qquad 6 &=10 \log _{10} G_{d} \\ \Rightarrow\qquad G_{d} &=10^{0.6} \\ G_{d} &=3.981 \\ E_{m} &=\frac{\sqrt{60 G_{d} P_{\text {rad }}}}{r} \\ E_{m} &=\frac{\sqrt{60\left(16 \times 10^{3}\right)(3.981)}}{8 \times 10^{3}}=0.244(\mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{m}) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 56 The current population of a city is 11,02,500 . If it has been increasing at the rate of 5% per annum, what was its population 2 years ago?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} 1102500 &=x\left(1+\frac{5}{100}\right)^{2} \\ 1102500 &=x\left(\frac{21}{20}\right)^{2} \\ x &=10,00,000 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 57 [latex]p[/latex] and [latex]q[/latex] are positive integers and [latex]\frac{p}{q}+\frac{q}{p}=3[/latex], then, [latex]\frac{p^2}{q^2}+\frac{q^2}{p^2}=[/latex]
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{p}{q}+\frac{q}{p}&=3 \\ \left (\frac{p}{q}+\frac{q}{p} \right )^2&=9 \\ \frac{p^2}{q^2}+\frac{q^2}{p^2}+2&=9\\ \frac{p^2}{q^2}+\frac{q^2}{p^2}&=7 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 63 Consider a square sheet of side 1 unit. In the first step, it is cut along the main diagonal to get two triangles. In the next step. one of the cut triangles is revolved about its short edge to form a solid cone. The volume of the resulting cone, in cubic units, is ____________
solution: One of the triangle is revolved about its short side, resulting a cone [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Hence},\qquad r&=1, \quad H=1\\ \text{Volume of cone},\qquad V&=\frac{1}{3} \pi r^{2} H=\frac{\pi}{3}(1)^{2}(1)\\ V&=\frac{\pi}{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 65 Corners are cut from an equilateral triangle to produce a regular convex hexagon as shown in the figure above. The ratio of the area of the regular convex hexagon to the area of the original equilateral triangle is
solution: Let the side of the two larger equilateral triangle =a [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Then side of regular hexagon }&=\left(\frac{a}{3}\right) \\ \text { Area of regular Hexagon }&=6 \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}\left(\frac{a}{3}\right)^{2} \\ \text { Area of triangle }&=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}(a)^{2} \\ \text { Required ratio }&=\frac{6 \sqrt{3}}{4} \times \frac{a^{2}}{9}: \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} a^{2} \\ 6: 9&=2: 3 \end{aligned}[/latex]
